data.note: In de Teekenschool werk je met de mooiste materialen, die altijd bij de workshop inclusief zijn.
Om te leren schilderen gingen jongens in de middeleeuwen op ongeveer hun 12de jaar in de leer bij een meester. In deze cursus wordt u zelf zo’n leerling.
In het Atelier van de Teekenschool kunt u allerlei workshops en cursussen volgen onder leiding van professionele docenten.
Duik in het hoofd van Rembrandt,  kijk mee met Hugo de Groot of ga op expeditie naar Noca Zembla
In de Teekenschool bevindt zich een theater met geheime kamers… Daar beleef je met al je zintuigen de verhalen van onze voorvaderen uit de Gouden Eeuw.

Ga op expeditie naar het ijskoude Nova Zembla, ontsnap in de boekenkist van Hugo de Groot of kruip in het hoofd van Rembrandt. In dit programma krijgen zowel de volwassenen als de kinderen een historische ervaring om nooit te vergeten.
Staande en zittende mannen tijdens een les in de Teekenschool, linksboven staat een rij bustes, anoniem, ca. 1925
Drie rijen mensen zittend achter panelen in de Teekenschool, anoniem, 1880 - ca. 1930
"Teekenen is schrijven en lezen tegelijk" Tegeltableau aan de zuidwand van de Teekenschool ontworpen door Georg Sturm met de drie Grati�n en een spreuk, Rik Klein Gotink, 2013
Oefenschool in de Teekenschool, anoniem, 1880 - ca. 1930
De Teekenschool ligt naast het Rijksmuseum.  En als je er een cursus of workshop volgt hoort er altijd een rondleiding door het Rijksmuseum bij!
Hokusai’s Ephemera by Louie Rigano. One of the 10 finalists of the Rijksstudio Awards 2015.
Vormvangen by Dorine Vink-Janson. One of the 10 finalists of the Rijksstudio Awards 2015.
Rijks Sunglasses by Juriaan van Berkel. One of the 10 finalists of the Rijksstudio Awards 2015.
Kraaglamp  by Kosek Jaroslaw. One of the 10 finalists of the Rijksstudio Awards 2015.
A Painting as Anamorphosis by Joost Guntenaar. One of the 10 finalists of the Rijksstudio Awards 2015.
Fashion outfits ‘Leven vanuit het zwart’ by Mattijs van Bergen & Job Wouters. One of the 10 finalists of the Rijksstudio Awards 2015.
Art Cards by Inbal Aderka. One of the 10 finalists of the Rijksstudio Awards 2015.
'White Lion' by Laura Ristea and Alin Tamasan. One of the 10 finalists of the Rijksstudio Awards 2015.
Runner-up for the 2015 edition of the Rijksstudio Award is Rijks Conserven by Alexandra Schijf and Birgitta van Langeveld.

The winners of the 2015 edition of the Rijksstudio Award are Lyske Gais and Lia Duinker. Their design of the Rembrandt Book Bracelet was voted as the best design inspired by the Rijksmuseum’s collection.
Make your own Masterpiece! The best design wins €10,000. Closing date is 15 March http://bit.ly/1aHqdfz  #Rijksstudio

Want to be a true artist like Salvador Dalí? This is your chance to create your very own design using ‪#‎Rijksstudio‬. Join our competition 'Make your own Masterpiece' and win the Rijksstudio Award! Closing date:15 March 2015. https://www.rijksmuseum.nl/en/rijksstudio-award

Weet jij al wat je gaat maken? Wij wachten vol spanning op jouw inzending! Doe mee en maak kans op de Rijksstudio Award en € 10.000!  Inzenden kan t/m 15 maart 2015. Meer info: www.rijksmuseum.nl/rijksstudio-award
Rijksstudio instructions

Make your own Masterpiece!  We invite you to get inspired by the Rijksmuseum's collection and create your own design using Rijksstudio. Every form of art is allowed – design, fine art, applied art, photography, video – and everyone can enter the competition.  A jury of design experts will select three winners. The ten best designs will be exhibited in the Rijksmuseum.
Rijks @home II
Winner of the Rijksstudio Awards 2014: Rijks Muse by Asnate Bockis en Rogier Arents
3rd place finalist of the Rijksstudio Awards 2014.  Delft Blue Hat by Josh Moll

One of the 10 finalists of the Rijksstudio Awards 2014:  Wallpaper collection by Ottoline de Vries
One of the 10 finalists of the Rijksstudio Awards 2014:  The milkmaid’s jug pouring light by Merel Kamp
One of the 10 finalists of the Rijksstudio Awards 2014:  Playing with tradition by Richard Hutten
One of the 10 finalist of the Rijksstudio Awards: Masterhat by Joost van Bergen, Dirk Schlebusch en Onne Walsmit

De laatste week van juli (26 juli-3 augustus) is het feest in Amsterdam: met de jaarlijkse Gay Pride maakt Nederland zijn reputatie waar als één van de meest liberale landen ter wereld waar het homoseksualiteit betreft. Samplers checked the quality of dyed cloth. Here Rembrandt shows them at work, distracted for a moment and looking up. One syndic is about to sit, or stand, so not all the heads are at the same level. A clever trick which, with the confident brushwork and subtle use of light, make this one of the liveliest group portraits of the 17th century. Originally painted for the sampling hall (Staalhof), in 1771 it was acquired by Amsterdam’s town hall. Rembrandt Harmensz. van Rijn, 1662

Maria Trip, daughter of one of Amsterdam’s wealthiest merchants, was twenty when Rembrandt painted her portrait. The artist placed Maria against a stone arch and devoted particular attention to the reflected light, the fashionable dress and jewellery. The costly garments are trimmed with strips of gold lace and Maria is wearing a profusion of pearls. Rembrandt Harmensz. van Rijn, 1639

Self-portrait at an early age, Rembrandt Harmensz. van Rijn, 1628.  Despite his lack of experience, the young Rembrandt was not afraid to experiment. In this early self portrait the light brushes past his right cheek. The rest of the face is cloaked in shadow. It takes a moment to realise that the artist is staring intently, directly at the viewer. #Rembrandt used the back of his brush to scratch in the wet paint, to accentuate the curls of his wild, unkempt hair.

Here, Rembrandt is about 55. In this portrait he represents St Paul, the apostle, identified by his usual attributes: a manuscript and a sword, of which the hilt extends from under the cloak.  The self portrait is typical of Rembrandt’s late style of painting: he used the paint structure in the composition, as in the folds of the turban for example.

The Jewish bride, Rembrandt Harmensz. van Rijn, 1665.  It seems that Rembrandt painted his subjects as the biblical couple, Isaac and Rebecca. Its popular name, the Jewish Bride, is a later invention.  The portrait is painted with an extraordinarily free hand, as in the sleeve, where the paint is especially thick and shaped to reflect the light.

The Night Watch, Rembrandt Harmensz. van Rijn, 1642.   Rembrandt’s largest, most famous canvas was made for the Arquebusiers guild hall. This was one of several halls of Amsterdam’s civic guard, the city’s militia and police.   Rembrandt was the first to paint figures in a group portrait actually doing something. Rembrandt used the light to focus on particular details, like the captain’s gesturing hand and the young girl in the foreground. She was the company mascot. www.rijksmuseum.nl

This street scene is one of the many genre drawings #Rembrandt sketched around 1645. With a few strokes he succeeded in establishing the architecture and framework for the composition. Two women are seated on the stoop of a house. The youngest is busy sewing as a child leans against her legs. Watching this tender scene is a third woman. Who these women are is no longer known, nor where the sketch was drawn. Clearly, however, #Rembrandt was drawing from life. www.rijksmuseum.nl

Self Portrait, #Rembrandt Frowning (1630).    One of Rembrandt's earliest prints belongs to a series of etchings in which he portrayed himself with a range of extreme facial expressions. Here he has depicted himself in an angry mood. He appears to have turned his head with sudden violence, giving the picture a sense of spontaneity.     www.rijksmuseum.nl

Legs spread, hand on hip, Croeser sits comfortably on the stoop of his house on Oude Delft in Delft. His 13-year-old daughter Catharina is looking directly at us. Jan Steen added a narrative element to the portrait: paupers asking the wealthy grain merchant for alms. Two years later, in 1657, Croeser acted as guarantor for Steen, who was then deeply in debt. Portrait of Adolf en Catharina Croeser on Oude Delft, Jan Havicksz. Steen, 1655.

Young and old are having a wonderful time: mother and grandmother are singing, the children are playing music and smoking, and father raises his glass. The note on the mantelpiece comments poignantly: ‘as the old sing, so pipe the young’. Steen’s picture brings the saying to life and warns the viewer: if the parents set a bad example, then the children will follow suit. The merry family, Jan Havicksz. Steen, 1668.

The fabulously wealthy Haarlem merchant and his wife commissioned their friend Frans Hals to paint their portrait in an unusual way. Seventeenth-century couples rarely appear together in a single painting, especially in such a nonchalant pose.  Hals included all kinds of symbols of love in the scene, such as the thistle on the left. A Dutch name for the plant was ‘husband’s fidelity’. Portrait of a couple in a garden, Frans Hals, ca. 1622.

This cheery young man is raising his glass as if to propose a toast. Although the fashion was then for intricate, detailed paintings, Hals applied his paints with quick, confident strokes. This style of painting gives the subject a real sense of movement. This is most obvious with the right hand. The merry drinker, Frans Hals, ca. 1628 - ca. 1630.
Officieren en andere schutters van wijk XI in Amsterdam onder leiding van kapitein Reijnier Reael en luitenant Cornelis Michielsz Blaeuw, bekend als De magere compagnie, Frans Hals, 1637
